metadata.title: Self-destructive PEG–BODIPY nanomaterials for photodynamic and photothermal therapy†

Self-destructive PEG–BODIPY nanomaterials for photodynamic and photothermal therapy†
Chaonan Li,ab Wenhai Lin, ac Shi Liu, a Wei Zhang*ac and Zhigang Xie *ab
Photoactive nanoparticles are an important platform for multimodal imaging and phototherapy of
tumors. Herein, amphiphilic photosensitizers were made from boron dipyrromethene (BODIPY) and
poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG2k) by using a thioketal linker, which is reactive oxygen species-responsive. The photosensitizers could form stable nanoparticles in aqueous solution. The resulting nanoparticles
could simultaneously produce heat and reactive oxygen species upon irradiation to achieve combined
photothermal and photodynamic therapy. The produced singlet oxygen could destroy the thioketal
linker, and accelerate the destruction of nanoparticles. In addition, the near-infrared fluorescence and
photoacoustic imaging ability of nanoparticles can reflect the biodistribution and destiny of nanoparticles.
This work highlights the application of integrated diagnostic and therapeutic photosensitizers in carriers.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Photoinduced therapy has gained widespread interest in tumor treatment because of its minimal invasion and low side effects.1 Photoinduced therapy is mainly divided into photothermal therapy (PTT) and photodynamic therapy (PDT). In PTT, photothermal agents produce a large amount of heat under the condition of light irradiation, which causes cell membrane destruction and protein denaturation to kill cells;2 and in PDT, photosensitizers (PSs) could produce toxic reactive oxygen species (ROS) under light irradiation.3,4 In recent years, most photoactive agents (PAAs) have been used for a single therapeutic effect in phototherapy processes.5–14 Some PAAs could achieve PTT and PDT at the same time, but need to be irradiated by two light sources.1 In order to enhance the therapeutic index and address such shortcomings, it is desirable and imperative to develop PAAs with dual function, including PDT and PTT.15–21
Recently, many PSs, such as BODIPY, cyanine and porphyrin, have been explored as new therapeutic agents with excellent
photostability and tunable photoproperties.22–29 Under the irradiation of excitation light, the electrons of PSs are excited from the ground state to the excitation singlet state. The electrons in the excitation state can produce a series of photophysical conversion processes when they return to the ground state, such as fluorescence, photothermal conversion, singlet-to-triplet transition and so on.30 The conversion of these photophysical properties can directly result in PTT, PDT, and fluorescence imaging (FI) of a tumor. In addition, the thermal energy generated by illumination could cause a wide ultrasound (US) wave. The US wave detected by the detector can be processed appropriately to obtain photoacoustic imaging (PAI). PAI is a very promising bio-imaging mode, which has the advantages of strong tissue penetration and high signal-tonoise ratio.31–33 It is very gratifying to design and synthesize a photosensitizer that can simultaneously achieve dual imaging and treatment of tumors.
Most PSs are hydrophobic, and bonding hydrophilic polymer chains is conducive to obtaining nanomaterial formulations.34–38 In addition, the hydrophilic polymer can isolate the internal hydrophobic PSs from the external water environment, which can enhance the stability of nanomaterials and protein adsorption resistance, prolonging the circulation time.39,40 As shown in Scheme 1, the hydrophobic BODIPY and hydrophilic PEG2k were connected by a ROS-sensitive thioketal (TK) bond, and the assembled nanoparticles (NPs) were obtained via the nanoprecipitation method. The obtained NPs could simultaneously produce heat and ROS under irradiation. Meanwhile, ROS could break the TK bond and destroy the NPs. As a carrier, NPs can release drugs by self-destruction under light irradiation, achieving controlled release of drugs. Moreover, the NPs could be used as near infrared fluorescence (NIRF) and photoacoustic (PA) imaging agents. a Key Laboratory of Polymer Physics and Chemistry Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Changchun 130022, P. sections.heading: Preparation of the PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs
sections.text: We first synthesized two BODIPY (R = H named BDP and R = I named IBDP) molecules with near infrared absorption, and then BODIPY and PEG2k were bridged with a ROS-responsive TK linker. The formed amphiphilic PSs (R = H and R = I) were abbreviated as PEG–BDP and PEG–IBDP, and their chemical structures were confirmed by proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) and mass spectrometry (MS) analysis (Fig. S1, ESI†). The synthesized PEG–BDP and PEG–IBDP could self-assemble into stable nanoparticles (PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs) in aqueous media. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (Fig. 1a and b) revealed that PEG–BDP and PEG–IBDP NPs had a regular spherical morphology. The size of PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs was less than 100 nm. The size distribution measured by dynamic light scattering (DLS) is shown in Fig. S2a and b (ESI†). The PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs had excellent colloidal stability, as evidenced by the unnoticeable size variation in water and 10% FBS (Fig. S2c and d, ESI†). The absorption and fluorescence spectra of PEG–BDP molecule, PEG–IBDP molecule, PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs with the same concentration are shown in Fig. 1c and d, respectively. The absorption peaks of the PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs in water were red-shifted relative to those of the PEG–BDP molecule and PEG–IBDP molecule in DMF because of the J-aggregation in aqueous media.41 The heavy atom effect of PEG–IBDP resulted in the weakened radiation transition ability and poor fluorescence emission. The decrease of fluorescence intensity of the PEG– BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs was the result of aggregationcaused quenching.

sections.heading: Photothermal effect of PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs
sections.text:
The potential ability of PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs to generate heat after irradiation was proved by a series of tests. First, the temperature changes of PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs are shown in Fig. 2a and b under the condition of different concentrations and illumination intensities. The heating capacity of PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs increased with the increase of concentration and illumination intensity. From the cooling curve of the NPs (Fig. 2c and d), we calculated the photothermal
conversion efficiencies of PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs to be 37.87% and 42.01%, respectively. Furthermore, in order to explore the thermal stability of PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs,

sections.heading: ROS generation of PEG–BDP and PEG–IBDP
sections.text:
The potential abilities of PEG–BDP and PEG–IBDP to generate ROS in vitro were measured by using 1,3-diphenylisobenzofuran (DPBF) and 9,10-anthracenediyl-bis(methylene)dimalonic acid (ABDA) as indicators. As shown in Fig. 3a and b, PEG–IBDP molecule (1.5 mM) and PEG–IBDP NPs (10 mM) reduced the absorbance of the corresponding indicators. On the contrary, the absorbance of the indicator did not decrease under the same illumination conditions in the presence of PEG–BDP molecule (1.5 mM) and PEG–BDP NPs (10 mM). The absorption spectra of DPBF in DMF and the absorption spectra of ABDA in the presence of PEG–BDP or PEG–IBDP NPs in PBS after irradiation are shown in Fig. S4 (ESI†). In addition, the photostability was monitored. The absorbance of PEG–BDP and PEG–IBDP was also almost unchanged whether as molecules or NPs under light conditions. It could be seen that the introduction of an iodine atom into the BODIPY core enhanced the ability of intersystem crossing (ISC) and generated singlet oxygen under irradiation.30
The generation of ROS was further demonstrated at the cellular level (HeLa cells) with 20,70-dichlorofluorescein diacetate (DCFH-DA). In the presence of singlet oxygen, DCFH-DA with no fluorescence was oxidized to dichlorofluorescein (DCF) with green fluorescence. The higher the singlet oxygen content, the stronger the fluorescence intensity. The experimental results are shown in Fig. 3c. Only PEG–IBDP NPs could produce singlet oxygen under illumination, but no singlet oxygen was produced for the control groups (PEG–BDP NPs with or without irradiation and PEG–IBDP NPs without irradiation).

sections.heading: Self-destructive behavior of PEG–IBDP NPs
sections.text:
The destruction mechanism of the ROS-induced TK bond breakage was proven via a series of experiments. First, PEG– IBDP molecule was dissolved in dichloromethane (CH2Cl2) and illuminated with 685 nm laser for 12 h at 4 1C avoiding the influence of temperature. The images of PEG–IBDP molecule in CH2Cl2 with and without illumination, and MS analysis of the illuminated substances, are shown in Fig. S5a and b (ESI†). The change of molecule solution color after illumination indicated the formation of new substances. The peaks at m/z from 1333.5 to 2436.4 were the residues of PEG2K. The peaks at m/z 1026.2 and 996.3 were IBDP. PEG–IBDP molecule only generated singlet oxygen under irradiation. This proved that the TK bond was broken in the presence of singlet oxygen. In order to monitor the ROS-responsive release of drugs, r-BDP as a mimic drug was encapsulated into the PEG–IBDP NPs to form PEG– IBDP@r-BDP NPs. r-BDP is a red dye and its structure is shown in Fig. S11 (ESI†). We measured the absorbance of PEG– IBDP@r-BDP NPs after different times of illumination, and the results are shown in Fig. 4a. The characteristic absorption wavelength of r-BDP at 635 nm gradually decreased with the prolongation of illumination time due to the release of r-BDP from NPs. Relative to the absorbance at 736 nm, the ratio of I635 to I736 declined with the prolongation of illumination time, as shown in Fig. 4b. In contrast, the absorption intensity of the PEG–IBDP@r-BDP NPs without illumination did not change (Fig. S5c, ESI†). Then, the destructive effect of ROS production was demonstrated at the cellular level. The emission of PEG– IBDP NPs was red fluorescence. In order to avoid the effect of overlapping emission light, we encapsulated green fluorescent BODIPY (g-BDP, the structure is shown in Fig. S11, ESI†) into the PEG–IBDP NPs, and the formed nanoparticles were named

The ROS production was stimulated by illumination for 5 min, and g-BDP was released after incubation for 0.5 h and 2 h, respectively. Then, the nuclei were stained with Hoechst 33258 and the results were observed using confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLSM). The intensity of green fluorescence in the light group was significantly higher than that in the dark group (Fig. 4c). This result indicated that the ROS destroyed the TK bond, and g-BDP was released from the PEG–IBDP@g-BDP NPs. Moreover, the zeta-potential of PEG-IBP NPs with and without irradiation (685 nm laser, irradiation 2 h) was monitored. As shown in Fig. S5b (ESI†), the PEG-IBP NPs had higher electronegativity after irradiation because the TK bond was broken.42

sections.heading: Cellular uptake
sections.text:
In order to study the cellular uptake of PEG–BDP NPs and PEG– IBDP NPs, HeLa cells were incubated with PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs (5 mM) for different times, and the nuclei were stained with Hoechst 33258. The results were observed using CLSM. As shown in Fig. 5a and c, the endocytosis was dependent on the incubation time. As time goes on, increasing red fluorescence intensity indicated that endocytosis of nanoparticles increased gradually. Quantitative analysis of the cellular uptake by flow cytometry (FCM) is shown in Fig. 5b and d and the results were consistent with the CLSM images. In addition, the HeLa cells were incubated with PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs (5 mM) for 2 h, and the cells were stained with Lyso-Tracker Green. Co-localized experimental results were obtained using CLSM and are shown in Fig. S6 (ESI†). The higher overlap indicated that PEG– BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs enter cells via endocytosis.
In vitro phototherapy with PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs.
Cytotoxicity of PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs was detected by using the 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) method. HeLa and HepG2 cells were incubated with different concentrations of PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs for 4 h, and treated with or without illumination. As shown in Fig. 6a and b, PEG–IBDP NPs (5 mM) caused cell death completely because of the double effects of PTT and PDT, while PEG–BDP NPs (10 mM) caused cell death based on the photothermal effect. Moreover, PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs showed little toxicity to cells without irradiation. To visualize cell viability, HeLa cells were dyed with calcein-AM and PI. The experimental results of live/dead staining were basically consistent with those of MTT (Fig. 6c and Fig. S7, ESI†). The cells in the control group were live with strong green fluorescence. PEG–BDP NPs (5 mM) and PEG–IBDP NPs (10 mM) caused cell death with strong red fluorescence under irradiation.

sections.heading: The imaging capability of PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs.
sections.text:
Kunming strain female mice were purchased from Jilin University, China, and cared for in an ethical and humane way. All the experiments were performed in strict accordance with the NIH guidelines for the care and use of laboratory animals (NIH Publication No. 85-23 Rev. 1985). All protocols were approved by the Committee on Animal Use and Care of Chinese Academy of Sciences. PEG–BDP NPs (Fig. S8a, ESI†) and PEG–IBDP NPs (Fig. 7a) had a strong PA signal and the signal intensity increased gradually with the increase of concentration. The column diagram of signal quantization is shown in Fig. S8b and Fig. 7b (ESI†). The PA imaging functions of PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs were further studied in live mice by tail vein injection. At 2 h, the PA signal of PEG–IBDP NPs in the tumor was clearly visible. With increasing time, the accumulation of NPs in the tumor gradually increased, and the intensity of signal gradually increased. The intensity reached the maximum

The single imaging method is not enough to guide the treatment of tumors perfectly. Therefore, the nearinfrared fluorescence (NIRF) imaging ability of PEG–IBDP NPs was investigated in mice. As shown in Fig. 7d and Fig. S10e (ESI†), there is no fluorescence signal 2 h after injecting PEG– IBDP NPs because of the aggregation-induced fluorescence quenching. At 6 h, the appearance of fluorescence signal in the tumor site indicated that the NPs were gradually destroyed in the tumor. The results were consistent with those of PA imaging. The similar results of PEG–BDP NPs are shown in Fig. S8d and S10b (ESI†). In addition, the NIRF imaging of intratumoral injection and quantitative data of PEG–BDP NPs and PEG–IBDP NPs are shown in Fig. S9 and S10 (ESI†). The fluorescence intensity was still strong in the tumor on day 7, which could provide long term imaging for tumor visualization.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: In summary, PEGylated BODIPY has been synthesized and selfassembled into nanoparticle formulations. The formed NPs not only possess robust colloidal stability and cytocompatibility, but also excellent phototherapeutic effects under irradiation. After introducing iodine into the BODIPY core, the PEG–IBDP NPs could simultaneously generate heat and singlet oxygen under the illumination of the same light source, achieving synergistic treatment of PTT and PDT. In particular, the generated singlet oxygen could break the TK bond and induce the dissociation of NPs, resulting in the release of drugs encapsulated in the NPs. The near-infrared absorption made it possible to achieve PA imaging and NIRF imaging of tumor sites, which were more conducive to guiding tumor treatment. This work provided broad prospects for multifunctional PS nanodrugs in the bioimaging and treatment of tumors.
